conclusion: To determine which light will first undergo total internal reflection, we need to analyze the angles and the refractive indices involved.
Light a and light b are perpendicular to the hypotenuse and enter the glass from the air.
Assuming the cross-section is an equilateral triangle, the angle of incidence into the prism is 60° for both lights.
Snell’s Law states n1 sin(θ1) = n2 sin(θ2), where n1 and n2 are the refractive indices of the two media, and θ1 and θ2 are the angles of incidence and refraction, respectively.
For light entering from air to glass, n1 is approximately 1 (for air), and n2 is the refractive index of the glass.
Total internal reflection occurs when the angle of incidence inside the denser medium (glass) exceeds the critical angle θc.
The critical angle θc is given by sin(θc) = 1/n, where n is the refractive index of the glass relative to the less dense medium (air).

conclusion: Light b will reach the critical angle first if it has a higher refractive index than light a.
